title: Account Banned Unfairly
body: Ok, so I have been playing League for about 4 years now and spent probably about $250 on the game. I played a game and there was a player on my team who was EXTREMELY toxic and harassed me. I was having a bad game and tried to ignore them. They didn't stop. I then tried to reason with them. They still didn't stop. Eventually, I was so sick of it I said a few mean things but that's all. I have never gotten a warning or a temporary ban or anything along those lines. But out of nowhere after the game, I log back in after the game crashes and I have a message telling me I'm part of the 0.006% of players toxic enough to get permanently banned. Permanently banned without any warning!!!!!! This is completely unfair and I would really like some help getting my account back.

replies.body: What RIOT does wrong is they only show your comments in the transcript. If the entire history was shown, it should be weighed against the initiator.

# If the initiator is reported, then *their own* actions  count against them. 

You are judged on your own behavior, even if it is in retaliation/ "defense". 

If someone is being a ♥ ♥ ♥ ♥  to you, defending yourself by pointing our their mistakes and pointedly speculating whether they have a neurological defect is not the way to go (not saying this is what the OP did, but this is usually what we see when people claim someone else started it so they shouldn't get banned). 

The best way to go about it when you notice someone is being a toxin, is to mute them. 
Mute them and don't try to reason with them. 
If you can't see their ♥ ♥ ♥ ♥, then it isn't going to bother you can you can focus on your own gameplay, continuing to communicate with the team via the smart ping system.

That's if you end up doing what they do.
Giving advice or telling them what to do can get you banned. I know from experience.

It depends on how you go about it. 

First of all, you need to consider why you want to give them advice. Is it because they are genuinely doing something with room for improvement, or are they not playing the way you *would like* them to play?
Most often people that are giving advice are going off the second reason. If you want them to play more like you and abandon their own playstyle, don't do it. 

It's pretty easy to gauge how people are going to react to criticism, and even when it isn't, it's always best to leave the tips till the post game. Why?

* If you are typing, you aren't paying full attention to the game, possibly putting yourself and your team at a disadvantage.
* Your teammate might tilt off the face of the earth (tbh I get super annoyed when people tell me how to play- they don't know my skill, my mindset, my limits)

> ##The basics of giving advice:

> **DO**
> * Add the player after the game and talk to them about it then. One on one is best, and you are less likely to have toxins chime in
> * Be nice about it, start off and finish what you're saying by pointing out things they did well, before suggesting one thing they could improve. 
> * Pick up on general things they could pick up on, rather than point out their specific mistakes. Chances are they could also point out a gazillion that you made. Best things are things you can link guides to, e.g: CS, warding, gank paths, builds, l2dodge
> * Open a discourse, ask them what they think you could improve on.
> * offer to play with them in norms or something so they can practice with at least one person on their side
>
>
> **DO NOT**
> * Point out their mistakes in game. Trust me, they already know. 
> * Harp on about one thing that happened early in the game for the next 20 minutes
> * Flame them, blame them, generally be a ♥ ♥ ♥ ♥.
> * Point out more than 1-2 mistakes
> * Force your opinion down their throats. If they don't wanna hear it, just leave them be.
